While the current prison system aims to deter crime and protect society, there is evidence showing its limitations. Studies have indicated high rates of recidivism, suggesting that incarceration may not always rehabilitate individuals effectively. Moreover, the system disproportionately affects marginalized communities, leading to issues of systemic injustice and inequality. Alternative models, such as restorative justice programs, have shown success in reducing reoffending rates and promoting rehabilitation. There are other methods to enhance financial stability and economic participation that, in my opinion, could better serve our society's needs. While I see your points about the benefits of technological integration in education, I still maintain my stance due to practical reasons. One of the main issues is the financial burden it would impose on the educational institutions. Not all schools have the budget to equip classrooms with high-tech devices. Additionally, the constant evolution of technology could render some devices obsolete quickly, necessitating frequent upgrades. These logistical challenges could potentially disrupt the steady flow of education.

While it is true that establishing clear legal boundaries and robust oversight mechanisms can help mitigate the risks of executive overreach, the potential for mission creep and gradual erosion of checks and balances still remains a valid concern. Even with judicial review in place, the interpretation of executive powers can evolve over time, leading to a concentration of authority in the hands of a few. This accumulation of power can undermine the fundamental principles of democracy and create a precedent for future administrations to further expand their powers beyond what was originally intended.
